title: Helicopter crash that killed 10 at pub ‘could have been prevented’
text:
A picture taken at the scene of the police helicopter crash at the Clutha Bar in Glasgow in 2013 (Picture: PA)

A fatal helicopter crash could have been prevented if the pilot had followed emergency procedures relating to low fuel warnings, an inquiry has found.

Ten people died when the police aircraft fell into the roof of the Clutha bar in Glasgow on 29 November, 2013.

All those who were inside the helicopter – pilot David Traill, 51, Pc Tony Collins, 43, and Pc Kirsty Nelis, 36 – died.

Seven of the pub’s customers were also killed, they were Gary Arthur, 48, Joe Cusker, 59, Colin Gibson, 33, Robert Jenkins, 61, John McGarrigle, 58, Samuel McGhee, 56, and Mark O’Prey, 44.

A Fatal Accident Inquiry (FAI) found the crash happened after the helicopter’s engines flamed out while the helicopter was airborne because the fuel supply tanks had been depleted.

The inquiry concluded that the accident was caused by Captain Traill’s failure to ensure that at least one of the fuel transfer pump switches was set to on.

Rescuers lift the police helicopter wreckage from the roof of the pub after a body was discovered (Picture: PA)

Helicopter pilot David Traill with police officers Kirsty Nelis and Tony Collins, as well as Gary Arthur, Colin Gibson and Mark O’Prey, Samuel McGhee, Robert Jenkins and John McGarrigle, who died in the tragedy (Picture: PA)

Sheriff Principal Craig Turnbull said the pilot had allowed the supply tanks to deplete despite there being ‘more than sufficient’ usable fuel available in the main tank which would have allowed the helicopter to return to its base.

The report found that both the fuel transfer pump switches were in the off position when the low fuel warnings were triggered.

It found that if Captain Traill had switched them back on at that point, the helicopter would not have crashed.

The Police Scotland pilot was killed alongside his two crew members and the seven customers. A further 31 people in the pub were injured.

More than 100 people were at the pub when the helicopter crashed as it was returning to its base on the banks of the River Clyde.

One eyewitness who gave evidence at the FAI told how the helicopter made a ‘spluttering noise’ before it fell from the sky while another said it sounded like a car stalling.

An Air Accidents Investigations Branch (AAIB) report published in 2015 found two fuel supply switches were off and the pilot did not follow emergency procedures after a fuel warning in the cockpit.

description: Three crew members and seven customers died when a police helicopter fell into the roof of the Clutha bar in Glasgow in 2013.
